Iaposll introduce you to the concept. A tutorial would be of great advantage to members of her majestyaposs government. After a stunned silence host Fiona Bruce appeared to come to the rescue and said: Some people are applauding it, some people are shaking their heads, referring to the programmeaposs virtual audience. Earlier in a discussion on the decision to send patrol boats to Jersey in a row over French fishermen he called it aposan absurd act of gunboat diplomacy.aposHe said: Itaposs a bit of jingoistic sabre-rattling. Andyou tell me or anybody does tonight that the despatch of those ships and the fact of election day are unrelated, I can say only that you will believe anything. Its juvenile, its down market, its not constructive, it doesnapost advance the cause of the arguments that need to be resolved. He blamed the problem on Brexit.

title: uk travel green list conference
story: NewsHolidaymakers set to get green list countries for travel today at pm press conferenceA Downing Street press conference is expected tonight - as the like of Portugal, Malta, Gibraltar and Israel could be on the Governments list of destinations Brits canfrom without quarantinemirrorShareCommentsByLizzy BuchanPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsHolidaymakers will finally find out which countries are on the Governments travel green list on Friday " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSun-seekers will finally find out where they can enjoy a quarantine-free holiday today. The Government is expected to unveil its travel green list in a pm press conference, with details of where holidaymakers can book an overseas break without having to isolate on theirhome. The Downing Street press conference is currently expected to be hosted by Transport Secretary Grant Shapps. The ban on non-essential foreign travel for England is due to be lted on May  under Boris Johnsonaposs roadmap out of lockdown. Today people will finally be able to begin planning a sunshine break when the Government publishes details of which countries are safest to visit from that date. But it is understood that the first green list could be small, with a source telling the Mirror that the Government plans to “play it safe”. Portugal, Malta, Gibraltar and Israel are among the countries which could make the cut for quarantine-free travel. The latest weekly rate of new Covid- cases per , people is . in the UK, . in Portugal and . in Malta. Ministers have drawn up a traffic light-style system, where countries are ranked by how safe they are to visit. The decision will be based on factors like vaccinations, new iants and infection rates. People will be able to visit green list countries without quarantining when they get back - although you will have to get a test before travelling and on day  after coming home. Holidaymakers ing from an amber list country must self-isolate for at least five days and pay for two private PCR tests.

title: who won local elections live
story: NewsWho won local elections where I live  Search the results in your areaResults are pouring in across England, Scotland and Wales between now and the end of Sunday. Search for the results where you live using our interactive postcode toolmirrorShareByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe Tories overturned a majority of around , in the Westminster seat of Hartlepool " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeLabour have had a grim night in the  elections after losing the Hartlepool by-election and a string of English council seats.The Tories overturned a majority of around , in the Westminster seat - Labour for  years - and doubled it in the other direction.The newly elected MP described it as a momentous day and claimed Labour had taken people in the area for granted for too long.But the elections are about far more than one Westminster by-election, however wounding for Keir Starmer.The vast majority of English councils are counting on Friday and Saturday, along with the Scottish Parliament. The Welsh Parliament is aiming to do all its counting later today. Key English mayoral battles will also be announced later on Friday and over the weekend.For a full rundown of results timings click here and for and for the full schedule of results so far click here.Butyou want to see the results so far through your postcode, you can enter it in the interactive tool below: It came as Steve Reed, shadow secretary for communities and local government, said the defeat in Hartlepool was absolutely shattering. Speaking on BBC Breakfast, he said: I congratulate Jill Mortimer on her victory, but it was for me, as a Labour Party member, absolutely shattering to see a Conservative MP elected in a place like Hartlepool after nearly  years.I think what this shows is that, although we have started to change since the cataclysm of the last general election, that change has clearly not gone far enough in order to win back the trust of the voters, and weaposve just seen that in spades in Hartlepool.Labour MP Diane Abbott, who was shadow home secretary during Jeremy Corbynaposs leadership, branded it a crushing defeat for Labour and urged Sir Keir to rethink his strategy. She tweeted: Not possible to blame Jeremy Corbyn for this result. Labour won the seat twice under his leadership. Keir Starmer must think again about his strategy.Both the Prime Minister and Sir Keir visited the Hartlepool constituency three times during the campaign.

title: ashes tattoos mcdonalds visits 9
story: AdvertorialFrom ashes tattoos to McDonalds visits:  unexpected things seen at British funeralsThese are some of the genuine things British people have asked for at their own funerals, according to Co-op Funeralcare - the UKs No funeral services providermirrorShareByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialHow us Brits think about and plan for our funerals is changing.Just one in ten people now want a traditional religious send-off, while two fths see funerals becoming more informal in the future, according to a report* from Co-op Funeralcare.Julia Samuel, author of Grief Works, says making funeral choices in advance is a great idea. She explains: As scary as it may seem to talk about death and our end of le wishes, it’s infinitely preferable to leaving our loved ones wonderingthey made the right decisions.Below, weaposve listed  fascinating things British people have asked for at their own funerals in recent years.. To arrive in a motorcycle hearse Some  per cent of Co-op’s funeral directors have been asked to source a unique hearse for a funeral.. To be buried with a Chinese takeaway . For a giant packet of Werther’s Original made from flowers . For part of the funeral to take place at a McDonaldaposs Drive-Thru Whilst three quarters of Co-op’s employees have had requests for funerals to take place outside of traditional religious settings, two fths of people say they didn’t know it was even possible to have a funeral at another location.. For their ashes to be turned into a tattoo . For their coffin to arrive on an Only Fools and Horses Hearse . For part of their funeral to take place next to the th hole on a golf course

title: computer system saw innocent post
story: NewsComputer system that saw innocent Post Office staff jailed is renewed for £millionEXCLUSIVE: Tech giant Fujitsu has been handed a shock deal of up to £million for its Horizon accounting software which was blamed for dozens of innocent postmasters being jailed or made bankruptmirrorShareCommentsByTom ParrySpecial correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsFormer post office workers celebrating outside the Royal Courts of Justice, London, after their convictions were overturned by the Court of Appeal " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe disastrous computer ­system that caused dozens of postmasters to be wrongly jailed has been extended for use by the Post Office. Tech giant Fujitsu has been handed a deal of up to £million for its Horizon accounting software. The sum is more than three times as much as postmasters received in settlement for having their lives blighted by the bug-ridden system. It was blamed for innocent postmasters being jailed or made bankrupt by creating shortfalls in branch accounts. Between  and , the Post Office prosecuted  postmasters. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section Following an historic day at the Appeal Court last month, some  postmasters have had their names cleared, and dozens more are lining up to ­challenge their convictions. Horizon – which the Post Office introduced in  and spent  years insisting was ­incapable of errors – was found to be riven with glitches by the High Court. In an out-of-court settlement in , the Post Office agreed to pay £m to  ­claimants. But after legal costs, they had to share £m, getting only £, each on average. Earlier that year Paula Vennells stepped down as chief executive of the Post Office, a position she held since . The deal with Fujitsu is endorsed by the Government which owns the Post Office.  Number of claimants whose names have been cleared so far yrs Number of years the Post Office insisted the system was glitch-proof £k Average payout for  claimants after an out-of-court settlement £m The amount claimants had to share between them after legal costs  Millions of pounds given to Fujitsu for its HMRC contract by Government The Horizon contract was due to expire in  but this has been put back to , at an additional cost of £m.There is a further option to extend it to , which would add another £m on top. Japanese firm Fujitsu has billions of pounds worth of contracts with the Government.  These include a five-year deal with HMRC worth £.m, a £m contract with the Department for Work and Pensions and it heads a consortium with a £m contract to implement Brexit checks in the Irish Sea. Two retired Fujitsu experts are being investigated by the politan Police over evidence they gave in courts that helped convict postmasters. The Post Office is believed to be trying to replace Horizon with a dferent “more user-friendly” IT system, but it is not ready yet. In an interview with Page Six royal writer Ingrid Seward said the stir that followed was deliberate.She said: “I can swear to you that, and he wanted to rock that boat. Quite why, I don’t understand, but he did want to. And then he did, and I don’t think he’s surprised by the repercussions or that he regrets it for a moment.” Speaking of Meghan Markle she said she was excited when the former actress joined the Royal Family, “but I knew she was going to have a problem, being American” she added. She said: “I think she had no idea she wouldn’t be able to say what she thought or wouldn’t be able to voice her opinion. That’s what she was used to all her le, and suddenly she’s in a straitjacket.”

title: how cope loss you live
story: AdvertorialHow to cope with loss when you live alone -  ideas to help you feel betterLosing a loved one is hard enough, but especially soyoure by yourselfmirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  APR AdvertorialNobody knows just how they will react after losing someone close to them. We will all be affected by grief at some point – something that has proved all too true for many people as a result of the pandemic. There is of course no “right” or “normal” way to grieve – everyone will experience their own emotional journey following a bereavement. We shouldn’t be putting pressure on ourselves to experience a certain sensation – like anger or acceptance – at a certain time, says Andy Langford, clinical director at Cruse Bereavement Care. Instead, we should be giving ourselves time and space.But it can be particularly hard when you live alone. The following advice from Co-op Funeralcare might help:Keep talking One thing that can give comfort is talking about your feelings with friends or family, so it’s important not to become isolated. Stay connected Use video and phone calls and social media to stay in touch. Arrange times to chat with people – having this in your diary can add something to look forward to and purpose to your day.  Stick to a routine As much as possible, try to get up at the same time each day, and prepare and eat meals when you normally would. If you can, get outside to exercise. Don’t be too ambitious Set yourself manageable tasks. Sometimes that will simply be getting out for a walk. Getting the balance right between being busy as a distraction and taking the time to focus on your grief is key. Look after your health Maintaining healthy habits for your physical wellbeing can help with your emotional welfare. As you focus on looking after yourself and practise self-care, remember that your GP will be able to offer advice on coping with bereavement

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeKate Middleton promised to wear a pink dress when she finally gets to meet a four-year-old cancer patient she has kept in touch with during lockdown. The Duchess of Cambridge chatted on the phone with four-year-old Mila Sneddon, who was unable to see her dad during the restrictions as she underwent chemotherapy for leukaemia. The youngster became a symbol of the importance of isolation in Kateaposs lockdown photography project after she was pictured kissing the kitchen window as her father, Scott, stood outside.Mila, who was pictured for the Hold Still initiative, was separated from her father in the first lockdown for seven weeks, after he had to go to work and could not risk bringing coronavirus into the family home in Falkirk.In a conversation posted on the Cambridgesapos new YouTube channel on Thursday, the duchess admitted she was not wearing a princess costume right now when she was quizzed by the youngster on her outfit. But she pledged to wear Milaaposs favourite colour when they eventually meet in person. Mila asked Kate: Do you have a costume  The duchess replied: Iaposm not wearing a princess costume right now, Iaposm afraid Mila. Do you have lots of dressing-up outfits yourself  Mila said: Yeah and told the duchess her favourite colour was pink. Kate added: OK, well I have to make sure I go and try and find myself a pink dress so that hopefully, when one day hopefully, Mila weaposll get to meet, and then Iaposll remember to wear my pink dress for you. Would that be nice  The image of Mila and her father, taken by her mother Lynda, was entitled Shielding Mila, and was one of  pictures selected for the Hold Still photography initiative, launched by Kate and the National Portrait Gallery in .  People of all ages across the UK were invited to submit a photo which they had taken during lockdown, focusing on three themes - helpers and heroes, your new normal and acts of kindness. The call, recorded last autumn, was released to mark the publication of Kateaposs new Hold Still photography book on Friday. Kate asked Mila about being apart from her father: How come you couldnapost see him for so long  Mila replied: Because he had to look after me because I went for a treatment. The duchess asked: Was it really hard not seeing him   Mila replied it was and told of the poignant moment they were reunited, saying: When he came into the house I was like, so surprised. The duchess told Mila: Itaposs a very small age to have a big operation. Were you very brave  You were a very strong girl, werenapost you  Mila proudly said to Kate: I know all your kidsapos names. The duchess asked hershe could remember them, with the youngster listing Charlotte, then George and finally Louis. The duchess told her how Louis, who has just turned three, has been charging around on his scooter. Louis has got so big now. Heaposs very quick running around and heaposs on his little scooter as well. Heaposs very quick. I canapost keep up with him, Kate said. Mila began the call by saying: Good morning your royal highness. To which Kate replied: Good morning. Goodness me, youaposre so polite Mila.  The duchess also spoke to Milaaposs mother Lynda, describing how she and the rest of the judging  felt that the image was such a powerful one. It tells the story of this particular time and a very personal story to you, so thank you very for much for sharing it, Kate said. Mila is now five and currently in hospital, which Mrs Sneddon described to ITV as a wee bump in the road.

title: mum sets record fastest labour
story: NewsMum sets record for fastest labour by giving birth in loo in just  secondsAstonished Sophie Bugg, , from Basingstoke, Hampshire, said she had just thought she needed to do a number two - and less than a minute later she was leaving the bathroom with a new babymirrorShareCommentsByCharlotte Penketh-King:,  MAY NewsSophie Buggs daughter Millie was clearly eager to arrive into the world " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum gave birth in what may be one of the quickest times ever with just one push - and  seconds. Sophie Bugg, , was  weeks pregnant when she popped to the loo in the middle of the night - only to leave the bathroom with a baby less than a minute later. Her partner Chris, , had to act fast as Sophie appeared outside the bathroom door with the babyaposs head between her legs. With just one big push, baby Millie was born into her astonished dadaposs arms. Despite her extremely quick arrival, she is doing well with her family at their home in Basingstoke, Hampshire. Full time mum-of-three Sophie said: She was ridiculously fast! One moment Iaposm texting my friend on the toilet about needing a poo and seconds later, Iaposve got a baby in my arms. Actually pushing her out from when the lady on the phone told me to push only lasted  seconds, it was so fast. I had no pains and my waters hadnapost broken, there was no realisation I was having her at all. It sounds really crude but it just felt like I needed to go for a poo.Have you got a birth story  Email webnews@mirrorI had messaged my friend saying I donapost feel great, then put the phone down from where I was sat on the loo and went to get up from the toilet. As I went to lt myself up, my body just got that feeling like I needed to push for a poo. So I sat back down, pushed, and as soon as I did that push, I knew it was not from behind! I put my hand between my legs and her head was completely out. I shouted to my partner for help, went from the toilet to outside my toilet door on the top of the stairs, did one push and she was out! This isnapost the first time that Sophie has been taken by surprise by her speedy deliveries.  Back in , the mum went to the toilet in the middle of the night and ended up delivering her first baby, Paige, now eight, just  minutes later. Little Paige was born still in her sac, which is why Sophieaposs waters didnapost break, and a paramedic was able to pop the sac safely. Sophie was then booked in for an induction for her second child Lexie, now two, to ensure she was in hospital this time around. She gave birth to Lexie just  minutes after being induced.  She said: My first baby was quite an experience - you donapost expect anything like that with your first labour, to just be at home and then all of a sudden youaposve got a baby. You donapost know what to expect. You get told all these dferent things from people like youaposre going to have a show, youaposll have waters go, so youaposre waiting for these things to happen and they didnapost for me so I didnapost think I was giving birth until her head was out. My second baby, the doctors were so worried with the fact of how quickly I had my first that they had me induced so I was in hospital with my second, which was a relief. But then my third baby had the exact same plans as my first, but came even quicker! I couldnapost believe how quickly she arrived.  My body doesnapost give me the signs of labour. My midwe and my consultant told me that I go from zero to baby, I donapost dilate like every normal person does. Sophie had been booked in to be induced a whole week before Millie was born but the cheeky little girl decided she was ready to come even earlier. Two days before her planned induction, Sophie woke up in the early hours of the morning on March  with the urge to go to the toilet. She texted her friend to say she didnapost feel well and that she was going to go into the garden for some fresh air but her pal quickly warned her not to in case she gave birth.  But by the time her friendaposs advice came through on her phone, Sophie had already given birth to her newborn after pushing out her head instead of a aposnumber twoapos. She did one more big push outside the toilet door with her panicked partner Chris, who works as a storeman, in front of her - and baby Millie was born. Sophie said: I sat on the toilet, literally did a push and had the feeling that I should feel between my legs because it didnapost feel like a poo. I put my hand down and I just felt her head! It was four in the morning, it was just so unexpected. I was calling Chrisapos name as her head came out but so much energy was going into me giving birth, I felt like the lady off of Titanic, shouting aposhelpapos but it wasnapost coming out loud enough! I thought heaposs not going to wake up but then when I got off the toilet, he was stood there in the doorway so he must have heard me. I just looked at him and said aposyouaposve got to do the rest!apos His face dropped but then the phone came out, he was talking to the paramedics, it all happened so fast.  My two other kids both woke up in the commotion as well so I had my eight year old poking her head round her bedroom door asking aposMummy, are you ok apos Iaposm like aposyeah, Iaposm ok darling, just stay in your room for a minute!apos I went from sat on the toilet to outside my toilet door on the top of the stairs, did one push and she was out! I asked Chris afterwardshe was alright and he was like aposyeah, that was mad!apos Sophie remained on top of her stairs cradling her new born with the placenta still inside her for  minutes before a paramedic arrived. The umbilical cord was cut and Sophie and Millie were taken to hospital to be checked over but were released after a couple of hours in perfect health. Sophie said: I was shocked when I gave birth to my first so quickly but Iaposm just in disbelief that I ended up giving birth at home once again and even quicker! I had no pain relief with two of my kids and the after-pain with my third was terrible from where I was straining so much because I thought she was a poo. I was left so sore for weeks - I literally felt like a baboon!  I hear peopleaposs stories and I know several people who have been in labour for  hours and I canapost possibly imagine that! Iaposve never experienced that - my longest labour was  minutes and Iaposve had three children. I do feel sorry for these people who have to go through it!

title: mums slug infested council house
story: NewsMums slug-infested council house horror as creatures found in baby’s bottleJade Lockhart, , cleans her house daily and salts her skirting boards but the slimy beasts just keep coming back, leaving her feeling physically sick with disgustmirrorShareCommentsByRoss DunnAyrshire Live Digital Editor:,  MAY NewsJade Lockhart, , with son Alfie, says she has had to throw out piles of clothes due to the slug problem " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum-of-three says her family is living in a slug infestation nightmare as she pleads for a new council house. Jade Lockhart has found the slimy creatures slithering over her two-year-old son’s bottle and even in her kettle during their four-year hell. The -year-old mum also claims doctors believe the slug problem in the familyaposs home is making her asthmatic son’s condition worse. Jade is pleading with council bosses to find her a new home for her and her three kids, saying she cleans the house every day and salts her skirting boards - but the creepy little critters just keep coming back. East Ayrshire Council said this week theyaposve carried out a range of remedial works in the past three years but pinpointing the source of the slug lair can be dficult. The mum of three in Kilmarnock, Scotland, told the Daily Record: Theyaposve been coming into the house non-stop for the last four years. Have you got a story  Email webnews@mirror Could you imagine getting up in the morning to make your wean a bit of toast and pulling it out the toaster and thereaposs a slug on it  Or you put your hand on the fridge handle and the first thing youaposre touching is a slug or you come downstairs to get your wean a bottle and your standing in about  of them  Itaposs no way for anyone to live. The situation has become so bad that the family has been put in temporary accommodation while council workers try to resolve the matter.  But Jade says local authority workers ripped up the flooring and re-sheeted the surface at the Broomhill Quadrant home in Shortlees and it did not fix the issue. Environmental health came out and said that the slugs arenapost coming from the back door, theyaposre coming from underneath the house in the foundations and they can fit through the smallest of gaps, she added. My son Alfie has really bad asthma. My doctor says that heaposs not well because of all of this. I got told from a social worker and another two health professionals we shouldnapost be living here because heaposs been unwell because of this. He has a really bad cough. Theyaposve been on his bottle, his dummy and toys through the night and heaposs getting up in the morning and playing with them all and obviously putting them to his mouth. And the infestation has taken its toll on Jade too. The mum says sheaposs cleaning the house every day and the situation is making her ill. Jade said: Iaposve lost about three stone in weight. Iaposve not been able to eat. It makes me physically sick. Theyaposve been in my kettle and everything.  My house isnapost black, Iaposm quite a clean person and iaposve got a lot of family help too. I have to hoover and wash the floors every night. The first Iaposve been able to eat has been in the temporary housing but this is only going to be for a couple of weeks. I donapost want back in that house. Jade says sheaposs thrown out three sofas and other household items ruined by roaming slugs. She said: They come up through the floorboards and Iaposve even found them in my washing machine.  Theyaposve ruined my furniture. Iaposve lost three couches through this Iaposve had to chuck out them out. I clean the couches but slugs eat dog poo and things like that so thereaposs only so many times you can clean them. Itaposs mentally draining me. Jade says sheaposs been on the councilaposs housing list for a year but sheaposs still at the slug-infested property. In a desperate bid to get rid of the creatures, Jadeaposs resorted to dousing her skirting boards with salt but it hasnapost deterred them.  And despite her best efforts, the slimy beasts still slither out from under her house in the dead of night and wreak havoc in the home. Jade continued: Iaposd say thereaposs easily hundreds of slugs coming into the house each week. Iaposve been told to put salt round my skirting boards and they still come every night. I canapost take much more. Blair Millar, strategic lead for housing, East Ayrshire Council said: We have been working with Miss Lockhart since October  following reports of slugs within her property.

title: romeo conman fleeced businesswoman 55000
story: NewsRomeo conman fleeced businesswoman £, pretending to be Barry Manilows palShaun Verner posed as a stage lighting boss to impress the victim on an online dating site and she made the mistake of giving him her bank details and went on to give up her job to start a new le with himmirrorShareCommentsByJeremy Armstrong:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsShaun Verner met his victim on a dating site" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA Romeo conman fleeced a businesswoman out of £, after pretending to be a pal of pop star Barry Manilow, a court heard. Shaun Verner, , was jailed for four- and-a-half years after he posed as a stage lighting boss to impress the victim on an online dating site. The woman worked for a multi­national accounting firm and owned a four-bedroom house but made the mistake of giving her bank details to Verner, who took control of her account. He bought tickets for two Manilow concerts and, to impress her, pretended to take a call during the shows, telling her he had been invited backstage by the Copacabana singer, . Instead he went off and hid. Richard Holland, prosecuting, told Durham crown court the victim “hit it off” with Verner, sharing a passion for travel and music. During a -month relationship he lied that he owned a four-bed home and earned £, a year running Stage Light­­ing Solutions, with international clients and “long-standing” ties to veteran singer Manilow. Verner told her he was due a large negligence payout from the NHS and she lent him £, for “temporary cashflow problems”. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  He also got her to “invest” £, in non-existent property in Portugal, promising “fabulous s”. He claimed to have  staff and that his son helped to run his firm but his son later told police he barely saw him. On a four-month business trip abroad, unwittingly paid for by his victim, Verner wore a suit to “meet clients” and used excuses to stop her seeing their property.

Council public health bosses in the area have previously confirmed cases of both the South African and Indian iants have been discovered in the town.It is understand that the council has now approached the government to ask for surge testing to be used in specic parts of Bolton, reports the Manchester Evening News. While figures from Public Health Englandshow the spread of the virus has been suppressed in some areas - including parts of Kearsley, Horwich, Westhoughton and Smithills - other locations are registering signicant numbers of new cases. Neighbourhoods in Heaton, Deane, Daubhill and Great Lever have seen a rise in recent instances of coronavirus, which have contributed to Boltonaposs increasing infection rates.Greater Manchester officials are believed to have scheduled a meeting on Friday morning to discuss the situation. It is also understood that surge testing will begin tomorrow, subject to government approval, although this will only target the areas where the virus is thought to be spreading quickly.  The latest figures show the borough currently averages a rate of . new cases for every , people, a rise of  percent on this time last week.This is the highest rate in Greater Manchester, signicantly above Trafford , which is second on the list. PHE data shows a sharp rise in the number of coronavirus cases in Bolton last week.  Of the  local areas in England, have seen a rise in rates, have seen a fall and  are unchanged. title: uk weather hail lightning 5c
story: NewsUK weather: Hail, lightning and -C freeze before temperatures soar to C at weekendThe relentless downpours of recent days will continue from today and millions of Brits will wake up to temperatures as low as minus  this morning as well as widespread frostmirrorShareCommentsByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  MAY NewsLightning and hail will accompany some of the worst downpours " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeForecasters have warned Brits to expect aposhail and lightningapos for a washout weekend before a mini-heatwave sees temperatures soar again. The relentless downpours of recent days will continue from today and millions of Brits will wake up to temperatures as low as minus  this morning. There will also be widespread frost for many along with showers throughout the day.But by Sunday the aposunseasonable weather apos will take a dramatic turn which will see balmy temperatures of more than  C in some areas. Speaking of todayaposs forecast Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: Yet another chilly May morning to come on Friday.But plenty of sunshine around especially during the morning before showers get going quite widely into the afternoon. He said that some regions will see biting temperatures drop to as cold as minus  in the early morning on Friday and there will be widespread frost. He added: Just about anywhere could be a prone to a shower by the afternoon, however the most likely places are going to be yet again Scotland, northern and eastern England. There the showers will be heavy at times, [with a] risk of lightning and hail in some of the livelier downpours. High temperatures of up to C are possible in the south with just single digits expected further north. The cold temperatures will continue into Saturday, with wet and windy conditions in a aposvery unseasonable weatherapos front likely to strike the country. Up to mm of rain is possible in some areas, the Met Office said, adding: Itaposs a miserable day to come for many places with that wind and the rain.  Meanwhile, on Sunday there are hopes of a mini heatwave on the back of the relentless torrential downpours and biting cold. London and parts of the south are predicted to bask in temperatures of C as many look ahead to sunnier climates this weekend.

story: NewsUnder-s to be offered AstraZeneca alternative vaccine over blood clot riskThe Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation has reportedly recommended the age threshold be raised up  after Britain’s medicines regulator reported new figures on clots last weekmirrorShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyReporter:,  MAY NewsCurrently, the policy of offering an alternative vaccine applies to the under- " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePeople under  are reportedly to be offered an AstraZeneca alternative vaccine over blood clot risk fears. Currently, the policy of offering an alternative vaccine applies to the under-s However, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation has reportedly recommended the age threshold be raised up  after Britain’s medicines regulator reported new figures on clots last week. A senior government source insisted that the change would not impact the UK’s target of offering a first vaccine dose to every adult by the end of July. It comes after one area in the UK is at risk of staying in lockdown due to an uncontrolled outbreak of Covid-. Moray, in north-eastern Scotland, has an infection rate of more than  cases per ,, with hospital admissions on the rise.Public health officials have urged the public to get tested eventhey do not have any coronavirus symptoms.They said thatthe spread is not controlled, the current restrictions may not be lted - despite lockdown measures being eased in other parts of Scotland. Chris Littlejohn, deputy director of public health at NHS Grampian, said the current restrictions are not preventing further spread of the disease. It follows news that an experimental new Moderna vaccine candidate has been found to aposneutraliseapos Brazil and South Africa coronavirus iant, Moderna Inc claim.Latest trials also found a third dose of either its current Covid- shot or the experimental new vaccine candidate increases immunity against both iants. The booster shots, given to volunteers previously inoculated with Modernaaposs two-dose vaccine regimen, also boosted antibodies against the original version of Covid-, Moderna said. The early data comes from a -person trial testing both Modernaaposs existing shot and a version developed to protect against the South African iant of Covid- called mRNA-.. Two weeks after the new jab, Moderna says both the booster shot and the tweaked vaccine increased the antibodies in the blood that can neutralise the two iants of concern. story: NewsWoman, , adopts -year-old dog and says people should not give up on the oldDog lover Marjory was devastated after losing her dog just before lockdown last year. When she found Jack, a Jack Russell Terrier, she decided to adopt him and they clicked straight awaymirrorShareCommentsByRachael NicholChiara Fiorillo:,  MAY NewsMarjory has adopted a -year-old dog " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA -year-old woman who adopted a -year-old dog is encouraging other people to consider rehoming older animals. Dog lover Marjory was devastated after losing her dog just before lockdown last year. She decided to browse the Dogs Trust Darlington website as her house felt empty without a four-legged companion.When she found Jack, a Jack Russell Terrier, she decided to adopt him and they clicked straight away, Chronicle Live reports.The woman, from Durham, said: “I’ve had dogs most of my le. Jack makes me so happy and seeing him happy is fantastic. “When I found out how old Jack was it made me, even more, intent on giving him a home because I couldn’t bear the idea of him spending the rest of his le living in kennels. “He is a very calm dog and likes to take le at his own pace, so this suits me very well. Marjory says she loves going for walks with Jack as he is calm and always stays by her side. She said: “I would encourage anyone thinking of adopting a dog to consider an older dog. “They are so full of character and are more likely to adjust in a new home , like Jack, they have spent the majority of their le as part of a family. Now Dogs Trust is asking people to remember that when it comes to giving a rescue dog a second chance, older dogs need new homes too and have a lot to offer.

title: woman who drank 15 cans
story: NewsWoman who drank  cans of cola and ate a takeaway every day drops incredible stKarina Dunford weighed st lbs at her heaviest and felt she embarrassed her family - but she reveals how she turned a corner and ended up dedicating two years to transforming her lemirrorShareCommentsByVikki White:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsKarina Dunford weighed st lbs at her heaviest" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeChampion slimmer Karina Dunford is dressed to impress after losing two-thirds of her body weight and shrinking from a size  to a trim . Karina admits to “eating myself to death” for years on a diet of fry-ups, takeaways and  cans of cola a day after becoming trapped in a cycle of depression. Weighing st lbs at her heaviest, her confidence was so low she “just wanted to stay in every day”, while husband Ian had to help her wash and dress. But Karina lost st after transforming her diet with help from a weight-loss group and now weighs st lbs. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section “I was so unhappy and my health was getting worse by the day,” said the -year-old who has been crowned Slimming World’s Greatest Loser. “I was eating takeaways, ­especially Chinese, every night and comfort eating chocolate. “I had a rough time. I felt I embarrassed my family. “I was bullied and felt no one cared about me”.  After multiple failed diets Karina, from Bridgend, South Wales, found her local Slimming World group and, in January , plucked up the courage to attend. Two years of dedication to the regime gave her a new outlook on le, as well as a new diet. She said: “I have the confidence to do things for myself and Ian doesn’t have to care for me. “I go to the gym, do workouts, go swimming and take long walks.  “I plan my meals. My favourites are spaghetti Bolognese or chilli con carne with lots of vegetables.” Karina has even persuaded her mum and brother to join up. Rhian, who runs the group, praised Karina as “the most determined member” adding: “It’s wonderful to see how much happier and more confident she is.” Before  Breakfast: Fried breakfast, followed by chocolate, biscuits and some full-sugar colaLunch: Pizza, chips, burgers or fried chickenDinner: Regular fast food takeaways, especially Chinese, as well as burgers or fried chickenSnacks and drinks:  cans a day of full-sugar colaAfter

news world-news china-mystery-animal-box-craze-"" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA new craze in which animals are sold in mystery boxes has caused outrage in China after a number of puppies were found dead inside. The blind boxes have become a popular trend in the country, with people buying packages without knowing which animal they will receive through the post. But on Monday, animal welfare activists made a distressing discovery when they found  small dogs and cats inside a truck in Chengdu in southwestern Chinaaposs Sichuan province. They found that the packages - which were disguised as regular express deliveries - contained a distressed puppy or kitten. Chengdu Aizhijia Animal Rescue Centre said the vehicle they discovered was carrying  animals, all under three months old, in terrible conditions - and a number of them had died. Disturbing footage posted on social media by the animal rescue group shows boxes piled up to the ceiling of the truck. They wrote: The cargo box is full of screams from cats and puppies. The rescue organisation added: We could hear them crying in discomfort. If the back door of the vehicle had been completely shut and no air was circulating, they would have suffocated to death.Volunteers tried to help the animals during the night, feeding them glucose water with syringes through holes in the boxes, a member of the group surnamed Zhou told Sixth Tone.Sadly, they could not save all of the animals and by Tuesday four of them had died.  The organisation said: The dead bodies of several pets were tossed on the streets by ZTO Express [delivery company] workers. Today, the rescue centre said they managed to bring the animals to their base and  were still receiving medical treatment. The courier company involved in the shipment of the animals, ZTO Express, apologised and said the person in charge of delivery safety in the region has been suspended. The company added it has launched further training regarding postal safety and national animal protection. In China it is illegal to transport live animals, but blind boxes have become increasingly popular, according to state media. There have been reports of similar boxes containing animals such as tortoises, lizards, hamsters and rats being sold on shopping websites Taobao and Pinduoduo. In most cases, customers cannot choose a specic breed northe animals.  The animals found this week were ready to be dispatched to locations throughout China, travelling up to , miles, according to reports. The illegal practice caused outrage in China, with numerous people criticising it on social media app Weibo. A person posted: Reject live animal transportation! The stench of corpses produces all sorts of germs that contaminate surrounding parcels... This is clearly an illegal act that is being done for personal monetary gain. Another Weibo user wrote: Buyers, sellers, the retail , and the couriers are all guilty. I canapost imagine how anyone can do this. China has come under harsh scrutiny because of its treatment of animals, with campaigners calling for an end to animal abuse.

title: six year old girl felt
story: NewsSix-year-old girl felt her soul leave her body after a close encounter with a sharkThe youngster was petried after feeling something bump into her and seeing fins and teeth come out of the water but had a lucky escape at Kalama Beach, HawaiimirrorShareCommentsByNilufer Atik:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsAnela was terried when the shark began flapping behind her in the water" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA little girl had a terrying encounter with a shark during a day out at the beach with her mum. Six-year-old Anela Rezentes was swimming near the shore when she felt something flapping about behind her. The youngster turned to see fins and the sharp nose of a shark’s face shoot up from the water. It then bumped her from behind and, realising what the creature was, she screamed and ran back to shore. Her mum Sheri Gouveia, who had been filming her daughter swimming, had no idea at first what had startled the youngster until she watched the video back on her phone.Ms Gouveia told Good Morning America : “When I watched the video back I saw the fins flapping around and I was like, ‘Oh my goodness, she wasn’t lying. It was a shark.”Anela had been enjoying an afternoon at Kalama Beach, Hawaii, with her mum when she felt something push into her and lt her slightly from the water. As soon as she saw the fish she yelled ‘shark’ and ran as fast as she could towards the shore, with the shark flapping around behind her and another swimmer nearby. Video obtained by KHON  shows the moment Anela ran in a complete panic. She was so petried she told the TV station: “My soul left my body,” adding, “I was very scared.” Ms Gouveia said her daughter was “hysterical” when she got out of the water and had only realised later what had happened after she’d caught the animal flailing behind Anela in the phone footage.  “She just started freaking out, saying ‘Mum, there was a shark in the water!’” Ms Gouveia recalled. “I kind of dropped everything as I thought, ‘no way’. There was no way – this would not have happened to us. “I’m just so glad that she got there that day with all ten fingers and two hands.” Luckily Anela, and her fellow swimmers at the beach, were unharmed. The brave girl also said it hadn’t put her off going swimming again. Experts who have reviewed the footage said it’s believed the species of shark which bumped into the six-year-old is a blacktip - which mostly feeds on fish and isn’t harmful to humans. end of the tunnel after being in “a dark place” during his injury nightmare.The former Watford striker has only managed five Dundee appearances since arriving last summer thanks to a succession of dferent injuries.An ankle problem delayed the start to his Dens Park career before he went down with a seemingly-innocuous thigh issue at Inverness in December.“It was the tendon in my right quad,” Jakubiak said.“I completely tore it, about an cm tear. It came from nothing, just a little clip pass out wide.“I’d never had an injury like this before and, at the time, it didn’t feel too bad.“I wasn’t sure what I had done. It felt almost like a cramp but I thought I was fitter than that!“It was only when we scanned it a few days later and found out how bad it was. Finding out I needed surgery was a shock.“It was only when I woke up from the surgery that it all hit me, how serious it was.“But I feel a lot stronger now and I just want to get back out there.”Almost four-and-a-half months passed between his injury in the Highlands to a substitute appearance in the - win over Raith Rovers.During that time Dundee have gone from revival to no hopers and then back to revival in their quest toto the Premiership.Now, though, they have found their groove and powered up the table to finish second after eight matches unbeaten.Jakubiak may only have been able to feature in four minutes of that run – and is critical of his own showing that day, too – but is delighted to be ing to fitness with Dundee in good fettle.mdash Alex JakubiakApril , He even credits the confidence around the camp as reason for making him work even harder to get back in.The Dark Blues are now four matches away from their goal of top-flight football.They await the winner of the Raith-Dunfermline play-off quarter-final this week.And Jakubiak says there will be no letting up from the Dark Blues, eventhey have a week off ahead of the semi-final.He added: “I was speaking to some of the lads and they said they couldn’t believe how quickly the season had gone but for me it’s the complete opposite.“Just being in the gym working, watching the games and seeing the guys train, as frustrating as it is, has helped me come through stronger.“I’ve got a more positive mindset coming back to training and the way the guys have been, it’s made me work that bit harder to get up to the fitness levels needed to match the rest of the lads.“It’s been a tough season physically but mentally as well. I do feel I’ve come out of what you might say is a dark place but can now see the light at the end of the tunnel.“The mood around the club has been very positive. We know the situation we’re in.#All season we’ve been going into games believing we can win because we are a big club and need to have that mindset.“We feel we shouldn’t be in this league but that’s the situation we find ourselves in.#Now we have got into this situation we don’t want to waste all the hard work we have put in till now.“So we’re going to push even harder from now till the end of the play-offs.”Jakubiak is pushing for ato action before the end of the season but knows how much is on the line for the Dark Blues.With that in mind, he’s aware game time will not come easily with promotion at stake.But he’ll do his part when called upon.“I’ve been desperate to get back out there from day one in the gym!” he added.“That’s my mindset, I’m just eager to play and show what I can do. It’s been tough and frustrating recently not being able to play.“It was good to get a few minutes at the end of the Raith game, it felt good.#Although I am very self-critical and I know their goal was partly my fault.#Even that, regardless of my injury, I know there are parts of my game I can work on and improve on. That will only come with playing games.“I will keep working hard and I will hopefully get a chance in these games.“It will be tough, though, because the lads have been doing so well.“The performance on Friday night at Queens was pretty comfortable. We were good all over the pitch, solid at the back and Jason got his two goals. He’s in great form.“It will be tough to get into the team but all I can do is keep working.“As much as I want to play every minute, the only thing that matters is we win the ties. Our ultimate goal is promotion.“So whichever team the manager picks, he has a lot of fit, strong, lads who are ready to go. Whoever he picks will do a good job.# Shaun Byrne is determined to relive the best moment of his career by helping Dundee to promotion # and he says the Dark Blues are a better side than his Livingston play-off winners" title"#Shaun Byrne is determined to relive the best moment of his career by helping Dundee to promotion # and he says the Dark Blues are a better side than his Livingston play-off winners# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp shaun-byrne-is-determined-to-relive-the-best-moment-of-his-career-by-helping-dundee-to-promotion-and-he-says-the-dark-blues-are-a-better-side-than-his-livingston-play-off-winners embed # secretFUAHaUB" data-secret"FUAHaUB" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no" Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest

or.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remIt#s one of the quirks of Scottish football that fourth-tier Queen#s Park for a long time called the near-, capacity Hampden Stadium their home.In fairness, at the peak of their th century-powers, the Spiders# attendances would have merited such a ground # and then some.Ten-time Scottish Cup winners # all before  # Scotland#s oldest club will find themselves in League One next season and, hopefully, playing at a redeveloped Lesser Hampden as a club resurgent in the professional game.For Dundee United defender Liam Smith, however, his experience of playing Queen#s Park is as an amateur outfit steeped in tradition.In a loan spell at East Fe in  , while on the books at Hearts, the right-back played against the Glasgow side in front of  or so fans at Hampden and was on the losing end both times.No doubt, it was an eerie experience for a young kid but one Smith, now , feels will stand him in good stead for United#s Scottish Cup semi-final against Hibs at a near-empty national stadium on Saturday.He said: “I never played at Hampden with Hearts# first team but I played there for East Fe against Queens Park!“It will be similar this time because it was empty so I know what that’s like.“I’m looking forward to it but just gutted it won’t be full because I’m sure both sets of supporters would’ve brought a great support.“Having seen what it means to the United fans from their send off for the quarters # and they’ve sold loads of season tickets # we know the support is there going into it.“Nobody needs to tell us how big a game it is and we’re all looking forward to it.”Although they are yet to get one over the Hibees since theirto the Premiership this season, Smith believes the Tangerines have as good a chance as anyone of going all the way.Smith, who captained the Jambos in a  Youth Cup Final loss to Motherwell at the national stadium, is hopeful for a positive result against his old Edinburgh rivals to set up a showpiece against St Johnstone or St Mirren.“I don’t think form, particularly, comes into it and they got beat on Saturday as well ,# the Fer added.“It’s just  minutes, two teams and the previous games against them don’t count for much.“It’s a one-off, the occasion takes care of itself.“We’ve done our research on them, we’ve played them a few times already as well so we know about them.“We’re building up to the game seeking a positive result.“It’s anybody’s cup now isn’t it “The Old Firm are always favourites but when they go out and it’s down to four teams everyone thinks: ‘What a chance we’ve got’.“I’m sure all the teams will be thinking that but, equally,we can put in a performance like we did against Aberdeen then why can it not be us ”Last weekend#s - Premiership defeat to Ross County at Tannadice wasn#t the ideal way for the Terrors to warm-up for Saturday#s massive clash # a repeat of the  semi.Although he is convinced the United squad weren#t distracted by the Hibs match as they failed to replicate their performance in a - quarter-final win over Aberdeen, Smith says they have to put the County disappointment behind them.“I don’t think so but you know it’s there because it’s a massive game.# he said when askedthey had one eye on the semi-final.“I think you’ve got to be professional and take one game at a time so there was no speaking about it through the week.Dundee United analysis: Ross County get it right against road-weary Tangerines unable to stop eyes wandering towards Hampden humdinger" title"#Dundee United analysis: Ross County get it right against road-weary Tangerines unable to stop eyes wandering towards Hampden humdinger# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united-analysis-ross-county-micky-mellon-john-hughes embed # secretZStjTHRm" data-secret"ZStjTHRm" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“It was all about focusing on Ross County but it wasn’t good enough over the  minutes.“It’s not the way we wanted to prepare, we wanted to go in with a bit of positive momentum on the back of a good performance but we didn’t turn up.“We weren’t good enough on Saturday but it brings us back down to earth after Aberdeen and we know we need to get ourselves going.“We don’t need any more motivation going to Hampden so we’re building up to that now and, hopefully, we show up better that we did against County.”To ensure they perform better, the Tangerines had a squad debrief in the dressing-room after the Staggies defeat and Smith revealed some home truths were spoken.“We were just being truthful with each other,# he added.“It wasn’t good enough, putting in a performance against Aberdeen in a big cup game and then not being able to back it up in the league.Ross County performance leaves Dundee United boss Micky Mellon with plenty of thinking to do ahead of Scottish Cup semi-final" title"#Ross County performance leaves Dundee United boss Micky Mellon with plenty of thinking to do ahead of Scottish Cup semi-final# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united-ross-county-micky-mellon-scottish-cup-hibs embed # secretKWHhLUg" data-secret"KWHhLUg" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“We need to find a level of consistency.“I know we were on a good run but we need to find that level going into next season where we’re performing consistently rather than plucking out whole performances now and then.“It was some home truths after the game but we knew that anyway. You don’t need told when you don’t perform on the day so we’ll put that behind us and focus on Saturday.”It was Hampden heartache in  but Calum Butcher is determined things will be dferent this time as Dundee United set sights on Scottish Cup Final" title"#It was Hampden heartache in  but Calum Butcher is determined things will be dferent this time as Dundee United set sights on Scottish Cup Final# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united-calum-butcher-scottish-cup--celtic-league-cup-final embed # secretJviLmQpnx" data-secret"JviLmQpnx" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest

or.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remNew figures reveal “unusually good” levels of activity in the Aberdeen housing market, leading to property prices beginning to climb.According to local experts, activity in the first quarter of the year is usually a good indicator of how the market is set to perform in the coming nine months and this year’s figures bring encouraging news.The first quarter numbers show that nearly % more properties were bought and sold between January and March this year compared to the same period in .Prices too are looking positive, with the annual house price in Aberdeen and surrounding suburbs rising .% year on year.This is no doubt welcome news after the shaky year the north-east property market has faced since the coronavirus pandemic took hold last March.Evidence that the north-east market was beginning to recover could be seen in the final quarter of , when property sales began to pick up.This has continued into , with , dwellings sold in Q.John MacRae, chairman of the board of directors of ASPC, has called these signs “invigorating” and adds that March this year saw the highest volume of traffic ever recorded on aspc, Aberdeen’s most well-known property site.However he cautions against any rash action, and reiterated that we are not out of the woods just yet. After all, the annualised house price change over five years in Aberdeen is -.%.He said: “The report released by the Centre for Real Estate Research at the University of Aberdeen Business School, for the first quarter of the year brings encouraging news.“This year, we have a strong positive indicator on prices, the first in several years.“The first quarter figures are always of interest because, by the end of March, we generally have a good indication how the market is likely to be during the year.“The last quarter of  had seen unusually good activity in our local housing market, leading to positive movements across two out of three categories. This was very welcome, given the year that we had endured. I recall endeavouring to dampen expectations for . I was concerned not to raise hopes.“It is invigorating, therefore, to see that results for the first quarter of this year continue to show improvement in our local housing market, albeit not yet of a comprehensive nature.“Nevertheless, the first quarter results reinforce the anecdotal evidence of practitioners that we may be experiencing a recovery in our market.“An additional sign of how our local market is doing is the increase in our website traffic. March this year has seen the highest ever traffic on aspc.“Compared to prices five years ago, our market remains down by .%. Compared to the last quarter of , it is down .%. Compared to the same time last year our market has risen .%. These figures require some context to help explain what I think is happening.“Last year was ‘unusual.’ After a mildly encouraging start the local market was stopped in its tracks by lockdown, only to recover, strongly, later in the year. Understanding just how busy the market was, last autumn, allows the first quarter’s result of -.% to be seen in context, as essentially stable.“Additionally, five years ago, the first quarter’s report for , indicated the annual house price change was -.%. The current change is +.% Given the mediocre performance of our local market since , this is a very hopeful sign.“Finally, the annualised changestands at -.%.“What all this means, I think, is this: Despite a severe knockback to activity, last year, we saw evidence of increasing confidence, and increased activity, after lockdown was lted.“The activity was not of “boom time” proportions but was welcome. The first quarter of this year appears to be continuing at similar levels of activity and is also having an upward effect on price.“Do bear in mind that we are in a recovery situation, prices are still, in the main, below the levels of , but there are grounds for optimism that the recovery will continue.”These figures have been compiled by Aberdeen Solicitors’ Property Centre Limited , in cooperation with Aberdeen University Business School’s Centre for Real Estate Research, relating to the housing market in Aberdeen.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

or.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remStaff at Aberdeen’s mass Covid vaccination clinic have been treated to some first class service with the help of grounded cabin crew volunteers.The charity Project Wingman started up last March, as the pandemic swept the country and masses of flights were cancelled.With medical staff flat-out caring for coronavirus patients, the organisation’s founders realised airline crews’ formal training could provide the perfect antidote.Since then, more than , aircrew from every UK airline have been volunteering their time to look after NHS staff at hospitals and clinics.So far they have set up more than  lounges at locations including Aberdeen Royal Infirmary and Dr Gray’s Hospital in Elgin.This list now includes the mass vaccination centre at P#J Live, with Project Wingman#s cabin crew members volunteering one day a week from their new lounge.Used to working in stressful situations, they have been empathising and offering support to staff at the centre – and keeping them stocked up with hot drinks and snacks and on their breaks.Clare Houston, NHS Grampian’s project manager at P#J Live, said: “We’re really pleased to welcome Project Wingman to the mass vaccination centre.“Obviously, the set-up here is quite dferent to a hospital, so we have had to think a bit dferently about how it will work.“However, they were really receptive to our suggestions and I know the space they provide will be much appreciated by everyone working on the vaccination programme.”Kirsty Cruickshank, a senior cabin crew member with Loganair who has been volunteering with Project Wingman, said: “We#re delighted to bring our latest lounge to the mass vaccination centre at the P#J Live at Teca.“The staff here are doing an incredible job and it’s great to be able to spoil them during their breaks with a little of our first class service.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: woman denies breaching covid rules by allowing patrons inside aberdeen pub to drink
story: A woman has denied breaching coronavirus regulations by allowing patrons inside Victoria Bar to drink alcohol in October last year. Tracy Allison, who is understood to have been a member of staff at the bar at the time, is alleged to have contravened part of The Health Protection Regulations . The -year-old, of Balnagask Road, Aberdeen, has now pled not guilty over the allegation in court.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

or.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remWith the Covid- vaccination programme now under way, we#ve put together a collection of Covid vaccine tracker charts to monitor the progress of the Covid- vaccine rollout across the UK.How many people have been vaccinated How many people have received the vaccine in my area Which demographics have received the vaccine When will I receive my coronavirus vaccine The Covid vaccine tracker below shows an at-a-glance view of the current proportion of the Scottish population who have received the first and second dose of either the Oxford AstraZaneca or the Pfizer BioNTech vaccination so far.The table below is an at-a-glance view of the total figures by group.Data on the number of people vaccinated was initially provided in a weekly report from Public Health Scotland, however there was immense pressure to keep the public more regularly informed so on January  the statistics began to be provided each day.The chart below shows the daily numbers of first and second doses provided.The chart below shows the cumulative number of people who have received each dose since the vaccination programme began on December .It#s also helpful to look at this data as a proportion of the Scottish population so you can see how the percentage of people vaccinated grows over time.The chart below shows the progress for each UK country.On January , Public Health Scotland provided this data broken down by vaccine type which is shown in the chart below.The map below shows the available data on the regional rollout of the vaccination programme.January  saw the release of data by local authority area for the first time, which is shown in the map below.Regional data was originally available on a weekly basis but moved to a daily upload on February . The chart below contains data on the daily number of doses provided and the population covered. Use the drop down box to select your area and the buttons to move between daily vaccinations, cumulative vaccinations and the percentage of the population who have received first doses.Similarly to the regional data, data by demographics were originally provided in the weekly PHS report # however on February  they moved to a daily publication schedule.The chart below shows the daily number of people who have had first doses in each age range, as well as the percentage of that population, covered.Public Health Scotland began reporting daily statistics on vaccinations by JCVI categories in mid-March. The chart below shows the percentage of each group who have received their first and second doses. The vaccines are being provided in accordance with the priority list drawn up by the joint committee on vaccination and immunisation . That list is shown below.Let us knowthere is something  you think we should be tracking by emailing lkelly@dctmediaFor as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

named eight Scots in their squad for the British and Irish Lions# tour of South Africa this summer.Backs Chris Harris, Stuart Hogg, Ali Price, Finn Russell and Duhan van der Merwe, as well as forwards Zander Fagerson, Rory Sutherland and Hamish Watson have all been included in the travelling party, following a Six Nations campaign where they beat both England and France.Of the eight selected, only full-back Hogg and fly-half Russell were involved in the Lions# last tour # a tied series with New Zealand in .Exeter Chiefs# Hogg, the Scotland skipper, was forced home early with an injury suffered before the first meeting with the All Blacks, while Racing #s Russell was called up as cover during the tour.The Lions, with Scotland head coach Gregor Townsend also involved as attack coach, will play Japan in the  Cup on June  before travelling to South Africa to begin their preparations for the first Test against the Springboks, which takes place on July .On  previous Tours#Representing four nations  millions in the #SeaOfRed# more will aim to add to that legacy#Here is our official #LionsRugby  squad#🤩 pic gkVpyolbmdash British  Irish LionsMay , Alun Wyn Jones confirmed as Lions captain
